Articles.analyse: The report reveals persistence and adaptation of ransomware groups, with rapid exploitation of known vulnerabilities (N-day) and increasing sophistication of TTPs. The use of AI by cybercriminals to generate malicious code (RaaS, PromptLock) marks a worrying evolution of offensive capabilities. Attacks against common platforms (SonicWall, SharePoint, VMware) show a focus on enterprise infrastructure weaknesses. The increase in macOS spywares indicates a diversification of targets. The impact is global, affecting various sectors and requiring multi-layered defenses and constant monitoring of emerging threats, especially those related to AI.
recommandations: Promptly apply patches for known vulnerabilities (e.g., SonicWall CVE-2024-40766).
Strengthen multi-factor authentication (MFA) and password reset policies.
Segment networks and isolate virtual environments (VMware).
Monitor activity on firewalls, SharePoint servers, and macOS environments for signs of intrusion.
Implement threat detection and response strategies (MDR/XDR) incorporating AI for behavioral analysis.

Articles.title: LOLBin Attacks Explained with Examples: Everything SOC Teams Need to Know
Articles.description: Article explaining 'Living Off The Land Binaries' (LOLBins) attacks, where attackers use legitimate system tools for malicious purposes. It details the nature of these attacks, their detection difficulty due to using trusted tools for unusual actions (loading modules, decoding files, hidden PowerShell scripts), and the importance for SOC teams to understand this modus operandi to improve detection.
mitre_ttps: TA0002: Execution (T1059: Command and Scripting Interpreter, T1202: Indirect Command Execution, T1548: Abuse of Alternative Authentication Mechanism)
TA0005: Defense Evasion (T1036: Masquerading, T1070: Indicator Removal, T1218: Signed Binary Proxy Execution)
Articles.analyse: LOLBin attacks represent a major challenge for SOC teams because they exploit trust in legitimate tools, making detection difficult via traditional signatures. The impact is systemic, as they allow attackers to discreetly integrate into systems, execute commands, steal data, and maintain persistence without triggering obvious alerts. The analysis emphasizes the need to focus on behavior rather than tools to identify suspicious activities.
recommandations: Implement advanced behavioral monitoring to detect anomalous use of legitimate system tools.
Develop detection rules based on specific LOLBin TTPs rather than file signatures.
Educate SOC analysts on LOLBin techniques and behavioral indicators of abuse.
Restrict user and process privileges to limit the impact of successful LOLBin execution.

Articles.title: Operation WrtHug Campaign Hijacks Thousands of End-of-Life ASUS Routers to Build Global Botnet
Articles.description: A global campaign called 'Operation WrtHug' has compromised tens of thousands of outdated or end-of-life ASUS WRT routers, primarily in Taiwan, the U.S., and Russia. Attackers exploited six known vulnerabilities, including CVE-2025-2492 (critical), to gain high privileges. Compromised routers are used to form a vast botnet, potentially by China-linked actors for espionage and masking C2 infrastructures.
indicator_of_compromise: Self-signed TLS certificate with a 100-year validity (starting April 2022)
mitre_ttps: TA0001: Initial Access (T1190: Exploit Public-Facing Application)
TA0003: Persistence (T1543: Create or Modify System Process)
TA0005: Defense Evasion (T1036: Masquerading, T1564: Hide Artifacts)
TA0011: Command and Control (T1071: Application Layer Protocol, T1090: Proxy)
TA0007: Discovery (T1083: File and Directory Discovery)
T1068: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Articles.analyse: This campaign demonstrates large-scale exploitation of N-day vulnerabilities on EOL (End-of-Life) devices, highlighting the risks of technical debt. The botnet is used as an Operational Relay Box (ORB) network for espionage, providing anonymity for C2 infrastructures. The impact is global, with a notable concentration in Southeast Asia and Europe, and represents a strategic threat to national cybersecurity and data confidentiality.
recommandations: Decommission or immediately update outdated ASUS WRT routers.
Disable non-essential features like AiCloud on routers.
Monitor for abnormal self-signed TLS certificates in network services.
Segment networks to isolate EOL devices and reduce their attack surface.
Implement rigorous vulnerability management for connected devices.

Articles.title: Ransom & Dark Web Issues Week 3, November 2025
Articles.description: Compilation of recent ransomware and dark web incidents. The DireWolf group launched a ransomware attack against a Pakistani automobile assembly and sales company. Massive data leaks from major South Korean companies were observed on DarkForums. The Akira group threatened to leak data targeting a South Korean lithium-ion battery company.
mitre_ttps: TA0040: Impact (T1486: Data Encrypted for Impact)
TA0010: Exfiltration (T1567: Exfiltration Over Web Service)
Articles.analyse: This report highlights the persistence of ransomware attacks, targeting various sectors (automotive, technology). The combination of ransomware attacks with data leaks on the dark web (double extortion) is a continuous and highly effective trend. The impact is financial, reputational, and operational for victim companies, with geographical implications in Asia (Pakistan, South Korea).
recommandations: Implement robust ransomware protection measures, including secure backups and network segmentation strategies.
Monitor dark web markets for mentions of stolen data or extortion.
Strengthen endpoint security and post-compromise activity detection.
Develop incident response plans for double extortion.

Articles.title: Sneaky2FA PhaaS Kit Now Uses Redteamers' Browser-in-the-Browser Attack
Articles.description: The Phishing-as-a-Service (PhaaS) kit Sneaky2FA has integrated 'Browser-in-the-Browser' (BitB) capabilities, enabling highly deceptive phishing attacks. Known for its SVG-based attacks and attacker-in-the-middle (AitM) tactics, Sneaky2FA now mimics legitimate login windows (e.g., Microsoft) and dynamically adjusts to the victim's OS and browser. Pages are heavily obfuscated (HTML/JavaScript) to evade static detection.
mitre_ttps: TA0001: Initial Access (T1566: Phishing, T1566.002: Spearphishing Link)
TA0005: Defense Evasion (T1027: Obfuscated Files or Information)
TA0006: Credential Access (T1552: Unsecured Credentials, T1539: Steal Web Session Cookie)
Articles.analyse: The adoption by PhaaS kits of advanced red team techniques like BitB significantly increases the effectiveness of phishing attacks, making them extremely difficult to distinguish from legitimate pages. This represents a major challenge for user awareness and traditional security tools. The impact is an increased risk of credential and session token theft, threatening corporate and individual security worldwide.
recommandations: Educate users about BitB attacks by training them to carefully verify the URL in the browser's actual address bar.
Strengthen phishing-resistant multi-factor authentication (MFA) (FIDO2/WebAuthn).
Deploy security solutions that dynamically analyze web pages to detect obfuscation techniques and abnormal behaviors.
Use secure web gateways and content filters.

Articles.title: Sue The Hackers – Google Sues Over Phishing as a Service
Articles.description: Google has filed a lawsuit against the operators of 'Lighthouse', a Phishing-as-a-Service (PhaaS) platform. This platform sold ready-made phishing kits that impersonated brands like E-ZPass, USPS, and Google, facilitating the theft of credentials and credit card data from millions of users. Google's lawsuit aims to complement criminal investigations with injunctive relief and discovery to prevent future harm.
mitre_ttps: TA0001: Initial Access (T1566: Phishing, T1566.002: Spearphishing Link)
TA0006: Credential Access (T1552: Unsecured Credentials)
T1078: Valid Accounts
Articles.analyse: Google's lawsuit against a PhaaS platform is an innovative approach to disrupt the cybercrime ecosystem at its source. The existence of such platforms lowers the barrier to entry for attackers, amplifying the global phishing threat. The impact is the potential protection of millions of users and brands against credential and financial data theft. Strategically, this represents an effort to dismantle cybercrime infrastructure through legal means, beyond technical measures alone.
recommandations: Strengthen multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all online services.
Educate users to recognize phishing attempts, even sophisticated ones.
Deploy phishing detection and brand protection solutions.
Implement DMARC, SPF, DKIM policies to authenticate legitimate emails.

Articles.title: The Cloudflare Outage May Be a Security Roadmap
Articles.description: An intermittent Cloudflare outage briefly took many top internet destinations offline. The article analyzes the consequences, particularly how organizations that temporarily bypassed Cloudflare may have been exposed to unfiltered malicious attacks. It suggests this event served as an 'impromptu penetration test' to assess the resilience of their internal defenses without Cloudflare's protection and offers lessons for diversifying security services.
mitre_ttps: Not mentioned
Articles.analyse: This outage highlights the over-reliance of many organizations on a single security service provider (SPOF - Single Point of Failure). The potential impact is exposure to known vulnerabilities (OWASP Top Ten) and bot attacks that Cloudflare would normally have blocked. Geographically and strategically, this underscores a systemic risk to the Internet and the importance of resilience planning, disaster recovery plans, and diversification of security solutions, especially for critical infrastructure.
recommandations: Analyze WAF logs and internal defenses during the outage period to identify exposed vulnerabilities.
Implement multi-vendor strategies for WAF, DDoS protection, and DNS.
Segment applications to prevent a single vendor outage from cascading.
Continuously monitor security controls to detect single-vendor dependencies.
Establish an intentional and tested fallback plan to bypass external service provider outages.

Articles.title: The Hidden Risks in Your DevOps Stack Data—and How to Address Them
Articles.description: DevOps repositories (GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, Azure DevOps) are exposed to risks such as weak access controls, misconfigurations, service outages, and accidental deletions. The article emphasizes customer responsibility for SaaS data protection and recommends automated, immutable, and geo-redundant backups, as well as strict access controls and not storing secrets in repositories.
mitre_ttps: TA0001: Initial Access (T1078: Valid Accounts, T1133: External Remote Services)
TA0003: Persistence (T1543: Create or Modify System Process)
TA0004: Privilege Escalation (T1068: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation)
TA0005: Defense Evasion (T1036: Masquerading)
TA0006: Credential Access (T1552: Unsecured Credentials)
TA0007: Discovery (T1083: File and Directory Discovery)
TA0008: Lateral Movement (T1021: Remote Services)
TA0040: Impact (T1486: Data Encrypted for Impact, T1490: Inhibit System Recovery, T1561: Disk Wipe)
Articles.analyse: Growing reliance on SaaS DevOps platforms introduces supply chain risks and single points of failure. Threats include ransomware attacks, credential theft, human error, and insider threats. The impact can be devastating for business continuity and source code security. Strategically, this highlights the need for 'shift left security' and compliance with industry regulations, with particular attention to data and access governance.
recommandations: Implement automated, encrypted, geo-redundant, and immutable backups for DevOps data (3-2-1 rule).
Implement strict access controls and regularly review user privileges.
Never store secrets (API keys, credentials) directly in code repositories.
Conduct regular security audits and configurations of DevOps platforms.
Educate developers about security risks and secure coding best practices.

Articles.title: Vulnerability in Chrome's V8 Engine Actively Exploited (CVE-2025-13223)
Articles.description: A type confusion flaw (CVE-2025-13223) in Google Chrome's V8 engine, also present in Microsoft Edge and other Chromium-based browsers, is being actively exploited. The vulnerability allows arbitrary code execution by tricking a user into visiting a malicious HTML page. CISA has added this flaw to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, emphasizing the urgency of patching.
mitre_ttps: TA0001: Initial Access (T1189: Drive-by Compromise, T1203: Exploitation for Client Execution)
TA0002: Execution (T1059: Command and Scripting Interpreter)
TA0004: Privilege Escalation (T1068: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation)
Articles.analyse: The active exploitation of this zero-day vulnerability in a fundamental component of major web browsers represents a high risk of arbitrary code execution and compromise of user systems. The 'type confusion' nature of the flaw makes exploitation discreet and potentially difficult to detect. The involvement of Google's TAG and CISA underscores the severity and likelihood of use by state-backed actors or commercial spyware vendors, with a strategic impact on government agencies and private organizations.
recommandations: Immediately update Google Chrome and all Chromium-based browsers (including Microsoft Edge) to the latest patched versions.
Enforce centralized update policies in enterprise environments.
Regularly audit browser types used within the organization to ensure they are up to date.
Implement endpoint security solutions (MDR) to detect suspicious browser-related activity and exploitation attempts.
